item.title: The new Ferguson police chief addresses the Michael Brown killing a decade ago
item.description: Ten years after the fatal police shooting of Michael Brown, a black teenager in Ferguson, Mo., NPR's Michel Martin talks to the city's new police chief. Troy Doyle has been on the job for a year.

item.title: We're not 'out of the woods' in the youth mental health crisis, a CDC researcher says
item.description: The latest Youth Risk Behavior Survey says 40% of high school students report feeling persistently sad and hopeless. Still, that's down from 42% two years ago, a small but significant change.

item.title: It's been a busy time at the Paris Olympics for U.S. teams
item.description: Olympic events are winding down, but there is still much to go. A highlight from the Paris Games Tuesday: American Gabby Thomas cruised in the 200-meter Olympic final to win her first gold medal.

item.title: Flooding from sea level rise is accelerating in coastal areas, new report warns
item.description: High tide floods – when water collects in streets or even seeps into buildings on days without rain – are increasingly common in coastal areas as sea levels rise, a new report warns.

item.title: The GOP continues a legal fight against mail ballots that arrive after Election Day
item.description: Ahead of this year's election, Republicans have been trying to stop some states — including swing state Nevada — from counting valid postmarked mail ballots that don't arrive until after Election Day.

item.title: A year after Maui’s deadly fires, the hills are still filled with flammable grass
item.description: After extreme fires last year that claimed 102 lives, Maui is trying to tackle the invasive grasses that pose a big wildfire risk. That could mean restoring the land to what it once was.
